page.title: 03W.CHILTINGTON HOBJON'S COTT.
page.content: { Hobjon's}was built in the 1600's. We think it was called Hobjon's because Hob means 'old'-{Old Jon's Cottage. The roof used to be thatched but it is now slate and stone. Today's lounge used to be a kitchen and washroom. The low ceiling was beamed and there was a hook to hang their pig on, and a hole in the floor so the pig's head could fit. The beams were made from{chestnut because the trees grew taller than{oak In the dining room they had an enormous{inglenook fireplace.}Salt was stored in a little cupboard to keep it dry and bacon smoked on a chimney shelf. The {King Post}held up the roof going all the way up the house. In the 17th century{Thomas Slater}lived here. He built the{stocks}by the church. {Slaters}still live in{Hobjon's}and are builders and slaters by trade.
